law.shorttitle: SAVANNAHCHATHAM COUNTY FREEDOM OF CHOICE SCHOOL ASSIGNMENT LAW.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide that the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and County of Chatham shall establish a county-wide school attendance district; to provide for a short title; to provide for the administration of the Act; to provide an effective date; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia:

Section 1. Legislative Intent. It is the intention of this Act to provide that freedom of choice will be the determining factor in assigning pupils to public schools administered by the Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and County of Chatham. Legislative intent.
Section 2. This Act shall be known and cited as the Savannah-Chatham County Freedom of Choice School Assignment Law.

Section 3. The Board of Public Education for the City of Savannah and County of Chatham shall establish a county-wide school attendance district to include all public elementary and secondary schools. The Board shall prescribe forms on which parents or guardians of pupils eligible to attend public schools in this system can indicate a choice of schools. Parents or guardians will be given the opportunity to make a primary choice and at least one alternate choice of schools anywhere within the county-wide attendance district on behalf of their child or children. County-wide district.

The Board will assign pupils to the school indicated as the primary choice by parents or guardians. In the event primary choices cause pupil assignments to exceed the capacity, or reasonable expandable capacity, of a school, pupils assigned to that school will be determined by lot or other strictly impartial method. Pupils not assigned to a primary choice school under this procedure will be
similarly considered for assignment to the next alternate choice of schools. Assignments.

Section 4. The school assignment provisions of section 3 will be completed by the Board not later than December 31, 1971. Pupils will attend the schools assigned under provisions of this Act effective with the beginning of the second semester of the 1971-72 school year in the City of Savannah-County of Chatham public school system.
For subsequent school years, the Board shall make pupil assignments on an annual basis in accordance with the provisions of this Act.
Section 5. This Act shall become effective upon its approval by the Governor or upon its becoming law without his approval. Effective date.
Section 6. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

div.p: Georgia, Chatham County.
Personally appeared before me Wanda Evans to me known, who being by me sworn, deposes and says:
That she is the Legal Secretary of Southern Newspapers Corporation, a Georgia corporation, doing business in Chatham County, Georgia, under the trade name of Savannah News-Press;
That said corporation is the publisher of the Savannah Evening Press, a daily newspaper published in said county;
That she is authorized to make affidavits of publication on behalf of said publisher corporation;

That said newspaper is of general circulation in said county and in the area adjacent thereto and is the newspaper designated and customarily used by the Sheriff of Chatham County for the publication of advertisements and
by the other officials and official bodies of and in said county for the publication of notices required by law;

That she has reviewed the regular editions of the Savannah Evening Press published on September 10, 1971, September 17, 1971, and September 24, 1971, and finds that the following advertisement, to-wit:

div.title: Notice.
div.p: Notice is hereby given that there will be introduced at the 1971 extraordinary session of the General Assembly of Georgia a bill directing the Board of Public Education of the City of Savannah and County of Chatham to establish one county-wide attendance zone and for other purposes.
div.pre:
Arthur M. Gignilliat, Jr.
Representative 89th District
div.p: appeared in each of said editions.
div.pre:
/s/ Wanda Evans
(Deponent)
div.p: Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 24th day of September, 1971.

/s/ Bryce S. Cockerham
Notary Public, Chatham County, Ga.
My Commission expires Oct. 28, 1972.
(Seal).

law.shorttitle: NEW HARALSON COUNTY BOARD OF EDUCATION CREATEDREFERENDUM.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to create a new Board of Education of Haralson County; to provide for the membership of said Board; to
provide for Education Districts; to provide for the election of the members of said Board; to provide for filling vacancies on the Board; to provide for the election of a Chairman of the Board; to provide for the appointment of a County School Superintendent by the Board to serve at the pleasure of the Board; to provide for the compensation of said Superintendent; to abolish the present Board of Education of Haralson County; to provide for all matters relative to the foregoing; to provide an effective date; to provide for a referendum; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia:

Section 1. There is hereby created a new Board of Education of Haralson County which shall be composed of five members to be elected by the qualified voters of the Haralson County School District as hereinafter provided. Each member shall be a resident of the Education District which he represents but shall be elected by a majority of the qualified voters of the Haralson County School District. All members of the Board of Education shall be registered electors eligible to vote for members of the General Assembly and shall have resided in Haralson County for at least one year immediately preceding the date of their election and in the Education District which they represent for at least six months immediately preceding the date of their election. Creation. Members.
Section 2. For the purpose of electing members of said Board of Education of Haralson County, the county shall be divided into Education Districts as follows: Election districts.

item.p: (a) Education District No. 1 shall be composed of that portion of the Bremen Militia District No. 1251 lying wholly outside the corporate limits of the City of Bremen as such corporate limits are now or may hereafter be defined; the Waco Militia District No. 1426; and the Buncombe Militia District No. 1225.
(b) Education District No. 2 shall be composed of the Tallapoosa Militia District No. 653.
(c) Education District No. 3 shall be composed of the Buchanan Militia District No. 1143.

(d) Education District No. 4 shall be composed of the Seventh Militia District No. 813; the Corinth Militia District No. 1585; the Draketown Militia District No. 1475; and the Mountain View Militia District No. 1077.

(e) Education District No. 5 shall be composed of the Berea Militia District No. 1512; the Steadman Militia District No. 1574; the Little Creek Militia District No. 1078; and the Felton Militia District No. 1335.

law.p: Section 3. There shall be one member of the Board of Education of Haralson County elected from each Education District. At the general election conducted in November, 1972, the five members of said Board of Education shall be elected for terms of office as hereinafter provided. The three members elected from Education District No. 1, Education District No. 2 and Education District No. 3 shall be elected for terms of office of four years each and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. The two members elected from Education District No. 4 and Education District No. 5 shall be elected for initial terms of two years each and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. All members elected at said general election conducted in November, 1972, shall take office on the first Monday in January, 1973. Thereafter, each member shall be elected at the general election immediately preceding the expiration of the term of office of the seat for which he is offering as a candidate for a term of office of four years and until his successor is duly elected and qualified. New members shall take office on the first Monday in January immediately following their election. Terms.

Section 4. Vacancies occurring on the Board which occur within the first two years of a term of office shall be filled by the remaining members of the Board electing a successor to serve until the next general election at which time a successor shall be elected by the electors of Haralson County to serve out the unexpired term of office. Vacancies occurring during the last two years of a term of office
shall be filled by the remaining members of the Board electing a successor to serve out the unexpired term of office. Vacancies.

Section 5. At the first meeting of the Board each calendar year, the members of the Board shall elect, by a majority vote, one of their number to serve as Chairman for that year and until the election of a Chairman in the subsequent year. The Board may elect such other officers as it deems necessary to properly carry out its powers and duties to serve for a term of office concurrent with the Chairman. A member shall be eligible to succeed himself as a member of the Board and also as Chairman or other officer of the Board. Chairman. Officers.

Section 6. The presently existing Board of Education of Haralson County shall continue in existence through December 31, 1972, but the terms of all members of such Board shall expire at that time, and such Board shall stand abolished. The Board created herein shall be the successor to such abolished Board and shall be subject to all provisions of law relative to county boards of education, and the members of such boards, except those provisions of law which are in conflict with the provisions of this Act. Existing board.

Section 7. (a) The Board of Education created herein shall appoint, by a majority vote of its members, the County School Superintendent who shall serve at the pleasure of the Board. The first Superintendent appointed by said Board shall be appointed at the first meeting of the Board in January, 1973. Such Superintendent shall take office immediately after his appointment. The County School Superintendent holding office on the effective date of this Act shall continue to serve the term of office for which he was elected and until his successor is appointed by the Board as provided herein. In the event a vacancy occurs in the office of County School Superintendent prior to the expiration of the term of office of the present Superintendent, such vacancy shall be filled as provided herein. No election for County School Superintendent shall be conducted in Haralson County at the general election in 1972. School superintendent. Vacancy.

(b) The County School Superintendent appointed by the Board shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the Board by a majority vote of its members, and the amount of such compensation shall be duly recorded in the minutes of the Board. The County School Superintendent appointed by the Board shall be subject to all provisions of law relative to County School Superintendents, except those provisions of law which are in conflict with the provisions of this Act. Compensation.

Section 8. Not less than 15 nor more than 30 days after the date of the approval of this Act by the Governor, or after it otherwise becomes law, it shall be the duty of the Ordinary of Haralson County to issue the call for an election for the purpose of submitting this Act to the electors of the Haralson County School District for approval or rejection. The Ordinary shall set the date of such election for a day not less than 30 nor more than 60 days after the date of the issuance of the call. The Ordinary shall cause the date and purpose of the election to be published once a week for two weeks immediately preceding the date thereof, in the official organ of Haralson County. The ballot shall have written or printed thereon the words:

blockquote.p: YES ()
NO ()

Shall the Act creating a new Board of Education of Haralson County and providing for the election of the members of the Board of Education by the people and for the appointment of the County School Superintendent of Haralson County by the Board of Education be approved? Referendum.

law.p:
All electors residing in the Haralson County School District desiring to vote in favor of the Act shall vote Yes, and such electors desiring to vote for rejection of the Act shall vote No. If more than one-half of the votes cast on such question are for approval of the Act, it shall become of full force and effect, otherwise it shall be void and of no force and effect. The expense of such election shall be borne by Haralson County. It shall be the duty of the Ordinary to hold and conduct such election. He shall hold such election under the same laws and rules and regulations as
govern special elections, except as otherwise provided herein. It shall be the duty of the Ordinary to canvass the returns and declare and certify the result of the election. It shall be his further duty to certify the result thereof to the Secretary of State.
Section 9. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

div.title: Notice of Intention to Introduce Local Legislation.
div.p: Notice is hereby given that there will be introduced at the Extraordinary Session of the General Assembly which will convene on Friday, September 24, 1971, a bill to create a new Board of Education of Haralson County; to provide for the membership of said Board; to provide for Education Districts; to provide for the election of the members of said Board; to provide for filling vacancies on the Board; to provide for the election of a Chairman of the Board; to provide for the appointment of a County School Superintendent by the Board to serve at the pleasure of the Board; to provide for the compensation of said Superintendent; to abolish the present Board of Education of Haralson County; to provide for all matters relative to the foregoing; to provide an effective date; to provide for a referendum; and for other purposes.
This 7th day of September, 1971.
div.pre:
/s/ Thomas B. Murphy
Representative,
19th District
/s/ Nathan Dean
Representative,
19th District
div.p: Georgia, Fulton County.

from the 19th District, and that the attached copy of Notice of Intention to Introduce Local Legislation was published in The Haralson County Tribune which is the official organ of Haralson County, on the following dates: September 9, 16, 23.

Representative,
19th District
div.p: Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 27th day of September, 1971.

/s/ Janette Hirsch
Notary Public, Georgia, State at Large.
My Commission expires December 26, 1972.
(Seal).

law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating a new charter for the City of Dublin, in the County of Laurens, and defining its corporate limits, approved March 31, 1937 (Ga. L. 1937, p. 1771), as amended, particularly by an Act approved February 12, 1952 (Ga. L. 1952, p. 2337), an Act approved March 21, 1969 (Ga. L. 1969, p. 2270) and an Act approved April 10, 1971 (Ga. L. 1971, p. 3752), so as to change the corporate limits of said City; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia:

Section 1. An Act creating a new charter for the City of Dublin, in the County of Laurens, and defining its corporate limits, approved March 31, 1937 (Ga. L. 1937, p. 1771), as amended, particularly by an Act approved February
12, 1952 (Ga. L. 1952, p. 2337), an Act approved March 21, 1969 (Ga. L. 1969, p. 2270) and an Act approved April 10, 1971 (Ga. L. 1971, p. 3752), is hereby amended by adding a new section after section 3B, to be numbered section 3C, to read as follows:

blockquote.p: Section 3C. In addition to the territory presently embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Dublin, the following described property shall also be embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Dublin and shall be a part thereof:

Beginning at a point where the previously existing corporate limits of the City of Dublin intersect with the southwesterly margin of a bypass road connecting U. S. Highway 441 with U. S. Highway 80, which bypass road is otherwise known as Industrial Boulevard; running thence in a southeasterly direction along the southwesterly side of said Industrial Boulevard to a point 75 feet southeasterly along said margin of said road from the point where the said margin of said road intersects the northwesterly land lot line of Land Lot No. 133 of the First Land District of Laurens County; running thence south 44 degrees, 1 minute west, a distance of 2,034 feet; running thence south 46 degrees, 3 minutes east, a distance of 2,141.4 feet; running thence north 44 degrees, 1 minute east to a point on the southwesterly margin of said Industrial Boulevard; running thence in a southeasterly direction along the said southwesterly margin of said Industrial Boulevard to the northerly margin of a certain public road which is variously known as Brown Road and as a westerly extension of Marcus Street; thence crossing said Industrial Boulevard in an easterly direction and continuing along the northerly margin of the said Brown Road in an easterly direction to the point where the same intersects the previously existing limits of the City of Dublin.

law.p: Section 2. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

div.p: Legal Number: 71215

Notice is hereby given of intention to introduce local legislation in the General Assembly of Georgia at the Special Session thereof which is to convene on September 24, 1971 for the purpose of amending the charter of the City of Dublin, as previously amended, so as to extend and change the corporate limits of the City of Dublin.
Notice given this September 4, 1971.
div.pre:
Roy J. Chappell, Jr.
Representative,
42nd District
W. W. Larsen, Jr.
Representative,
42nd District

div.p: Georgia, Fulton County.

Personally appeared before me, the undersigned authority, duly authorized to administer oaths, W. W. Larsen, Jr. who, on oath, deposes and says that he is Representative from the 42nd District, and that the attached copy of Notice of Intention to Introduce Local Legislation was published in the Dublin Courier-Herald which is the official organ of Laurens County, on the following dates: September 4, 11, 18, 1971.
div.pre:
/s/ W. W. Larsen, Jr.
Representative,
42nd District
div.p: Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 28th day of September, 1971.
div.pre:
/s/ Pamela R. Little
Notary Public, Georgia State at Large.
My Commission expires Dec. 13, 1974.
(Seal).

law.shorttitle: COUNTY COMMISSION ON EFFICIENCY AND ECONOMY IN GOVERNMENT ACT AMENDED. (400,000-600,000)
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating a County Commission on Efficiency and Economy in Government in each county of this State having a population of not less than 400,000 and not more than 600,000 according to the 1970 United States Decennial Census, or any future such census, approved April 10, 1971 (Ga. L. 1971, p. 3425), so as to change the date upon which such Commission shall be abolished; to provide an effective date; to repeal conflicting laws; and for other purposes.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia:

Section 1. An Act creating a County Commission on Efficiency and Economy in Government in each county of this State having a population of not less than 400,000 and not more than 600,000 according to the 1970 United States Decennial Census, or any future such census, approved April 10, 1971 (Ga. L. 1971, p. 3425), is hereby amended by deleting from Section 7 thereof the following:

blockquote.p: November 10, 1971

law.p: and inserting in lieu thereof the following:

blockquote.p: April 1, 1972,

law.p: so that when so amended Section 7 shall read as follows:

blockquote.p: Section 7. All of the functions, powers and duties of the Commission described in this Act shall be completed by April 1, 1972, at which time the Commission shall stand abolished.

law.p: Section 2. This Act shall become effective upon its approval by the Governor or upon its becoming law without his approval. Effective date.
Section 3. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

note.p: COMPILER'S NOTE: This Act was received from the Executive Department on 11-13-71. This Act was received by the Executive Department on 10-12-71 after the General Assembly adjourned on October 8, 1971, and it does not bear the Governor's signature of approval.
